text: this is Seth my dens reporting from
Bangkok for the New York Times and the
International Herald Tribune the Hooda
has always projected itself as the
country's protector and it's difficult
for it now to have to admit that it
needs outside help to take care of its
own people and so it's trying to project
on television to the citizens of them
are that it's the ones who are taking
care of him so there are photo ops for
generals and members of bones and the
record file of soldiers giving out
packets of relief food sawing up trees
that have fallen down in an attempt to
show that they have everything under
control and in fact that is something
that they say from time to time in the
press is that they have things under
control the situation is returning to
normal as if everything was still okay
in the hands of the Hansa under the
supervision of 10 min of national
disaster preparedness Central Committee
Prime Minister generate they say
commander Brigadier General Joss we went
to see site areas they're still making
it very difficult for outside agencies
to bring aid in within the country a
certain amount of distribution is going
on from stocks that are there on the
ground and those are being carried out
by members of the non-governmental
agencies using Burmese staff that's
quite apart from any efforts that the
military may be making to help the
people as well the hook is going ahead
on Saturday with a constitutional
referendum that they've planned for a
long time and a lot of people question
their priorities at a time when they
should be focusing on the disaster but
their priority is to legitimize
themselves through this constitutional
referendum and they are diverting
resources to carrying out that vote and
the display of their help to the public
can be seen partly as an attempt to win
paper is a vote although nobody believes
that they could possibly lose the vote
they're in charge of the counting and
they're sure to win
